bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, March 3, 1925

div1.p: Griffitts describes the survival of mosquito larvae in cold conditions, and provides news of his family.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, March 3, 1925
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
519 Dexter Avenue,
Montgomery, Alabama,
March 3, 1925.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I thank you very much for calling my attention to
Curry's article, which I have not seen. I shall be glad
if it is not much trouble for you to send it to me. I
should take this Journal, but have to deny myself of
several publications and books on account of the cost.
I will return your copy when I have read it.

Following up my larvae which I wrote you of a few days
ago: the temperature last night got down to 26F. here, and
the water was frozen in the quart mason jar outdoors. Ice
covered the top of the water, was all around the sides and
the bottom and needles of it throughout. A full grown larva--
crucians, I suspect, for all those that have developed have
been of this species--was quite active around the air bub-
bles in the incompletely frozen part. One of the imagos
was resting at a slight angle on the ice. The imagos had
three days before fed on cocoa-milk. A quad. caught gorged
in the stable was resting on the cloth cover in another
bottle over the frozen water below, but did not attempt to
fly when disturbed.

About the children: Mary Thomas is a prize, doing well in
school where she is quite a favorite, keeping the house
supplied and generally taking care of affairs in fine shape.
She is now past fourteen and is quite a well-developed
young woman. The others took quite naturally and kindly to
her “superiority” and never question it in the least. They
are always glad to know that you enquire for them.
